questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of vomiting and diarrhea. The patient had seafood at a restaurant three days ago and subsequently developed intractable nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He has not been able to tolerate oral intake for the past 3 days. He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 99.9 F, pulse is 114/min, blood pressure is 96/56 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Abdominal exam is significant for mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory Test  
Result
Sodium
134 g/dL  
Potassium
3.3 mEq/L
Chloride
105 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
31 mEq/L  
BUN
30 mg/dL  
Creatinine
1.6 mg/dL (baseline 0.9)
questions.solution:
This patient with hypovolemia and increased creatinine from baseline can be diagnosed with prerenal acute kidney injury and should be treated with intravenous IV saline.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden compromise of kidney function, leading to an increase of nitrogenous waste products in blood including creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). AKI is defined by any of the following criteria:

  • Increase in serum creatinine by at least 0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours
  • Increase in serum creatinine by at least 1.5 times baseline (which is known or presumed to have been drawn within the prior 7 days)
  • Decreased urine output of less than 0.5 ml/kg/h for 6 hours
AKI can be characterized as prerenal, intrinsic renal, or postrenal. Prerenal AKI, also known as prerenal azotemia, refers to AKI that occurs when renal perfusion diminishes, impairing the kidney’s ability to remove nitrogenous waste from the blood. Causes of prerenal AKI can be grouped into four main categories: medications, hypovolemia, systemic vasodilation, and decreased cardiac output.

Patients with pre-renal AKI from volume depletion often have a history of vomiting, diarrhea, or bleeding. Physical examination may reveal signs of dehydration, like dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and hypotension. This patient is suffering from acute gastroenteritis causing him to have nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Treatment should be focused on addressing the underlying cause of hypovolemia and intravascular volume resuscitation with intravenous fluids.  

Option Analysis

❌ Consult nephrology for hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is reserved for patients with severe acute kidney injury (AKI) and life-threatening complications such as hyperkalemia, volume overload, or acidemia. This patient's presentation suggests prerenal AKI due to volume depletion, which is primarily treated with intravascular volume repletion.  
❌ Administer intravenous loop furosemide:
Incorrect: Intravenous loop diuretics increase urine output by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Administering loop diuretics to a volume-depleted patient could worsen the prerenal acute kidney injury.  
❌ Administer intravenous albumin:
Incorrect: Intravenous albumin can act as a volume expander in cases of hepatorenal syndrome. This patient with prerenal acute kidney injury secondary to dehydration has no specific indication for albumin administration. Instead, isotonic saline is the preferred initial fluid for volume repletion.  
✅ Administer intravenous isotonic saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start oral rehydration:
Incorrect: In acute cases of severe dehydration with prerenal AKI, rapid intravascular volume expansion with intravenous isotonic saline is the initial step in management.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents to clinic with swelling around his eyes and dark-colored urine for three days. He reports a sore throat two weeks ago for which he did not seek treatment. He has no fever, rash, abdominal pain, or joint swelling. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg, heart rate is 84 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. Periorbital edema is present bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. No rash is present, and joint examination is within normal limits. No costovertebral angle tenderness is noted. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory Test      Result     
 Serum creatinine      2.1 mg/dL (baseline 0.7 mg/dL 6 months ago)     
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)      38 mg/dL     
 C3 complement level      Low     
 C4 complement level      Normal     
 Urinalysis      Mild proteinuria, hematuria with red blood cell (RBC) casts     
 Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titer      Elevated
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recently untreated sore throat and acute kidney injury (AKI). He is found to have hypertension, periorbital edema, dark-colored urine, and an elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titer. In addition, he has low C3 and normal C4 levels and urinalysis findings of hematuria with red blood cell casts, consistent with nephritic syndrome. The most likely diagnosis is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).      

Formulating and prioritizing a differential diagnosis for an adult with acute kidney injury (AKI) begins first with distinguishing between prerenal, intrinsic, and postrenal etiologies based on history, physical examination, and initial laboratory findings. Prerenal AKI, often due to hypovolemia or decreased renal perfusion, can be suggested by a history of volume loss, medications like non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or heart failure, confirmed with an elevated BUN-to-creatinine ratio and low fractional excretion of sodium (FENa <1%). Intrinsic AKI, which can be caused by acute tubular necrosis or glomerulonephritis among other causes, may present with muddy brown casts or red blood cell casts, respectively, on urinalysis. Postrenal AKI, caused by urinary tract obstruction, is suspected in patients with voiding symptoms or hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound. Additional tests, such as renal ultrasound, urine microscopy, and complement levels, as well as serologic markers (e.g., antinuclear antibody or anti-streptolysin O titer), may be required to confirm a diagnosis and guide management.   

Option Analysis

❌ IgA nephropathy:
Incorrect: IgA nephropathy typically presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria following 1–2 days of an upper respiratory tract infection. This patient’s symptoms occurred 2 weeks after the infection, making IgA nephropathy less likely
✅ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Minimal change disease:
Incorrect: Minimal change disease is associated with nephrotic syndrome (e.g., massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema) rather than nephritic features such as hematuria and red blood cell casts.  
❌ Anti–glomerular basement membrane disease:
Incorrect: Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease, also known as Goodpasture syndrome, involves both kidney and lungs.Patients often present with hemoptysis and hematuria. This patient has no respiratory symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Lupus nephritis:
Incorrect: Lupus nephritis would present with both low C3 and C4 levels. And typically with systemic symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or with a history of SLE.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath for one week. He reports orthopnea and dyspnea on exertion and has also had ongoing difficulty fully emptying his bladder. The patient's medical history is significant for obesity and hypertension, but the patient has not taken any blood pressure medications in several months. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 205/77 mmHg, heart rate is 130 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals faint bilateral rales and 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Suprapubic fullness is noted, and bladder scanning shows approximately 1L of urine. Laboratory studies are detailed below. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals peaked T-waves and QRS widening. The patient receives intravenous furosemide, calcium gluconate, insulin with dextrose, and albuterol. A Foley catheter is placed without complication. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Serum chemistry    
 Laboratory value     Result    
 Sodium      142 mEq/L    
 Potassium      7.1 mEq/L    
 Chloride      95 mEq/L    
 BUN     130 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      11.2 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL 2 months ago)    
 Albumin      3.2 g/dL    
 Venous pH     7.28
questions.solution:
This patient presents with volume overload and postrenal acute kidney injury (AKI). Workup shows hyperkalemia with concerning ECG changes (e.g., peaked T-waves, QRS prolongation). Although the patient is receiving temporizing measures for this electrolyte disturbance, the best next step is emergent hemodialysis to rapidly and definitively remove potassium. Failure to do so could result in lethal arrhythmias.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined by a sudden decline in renal function leading to electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. It is classified into prerenal, renal (intrinsic), and postrenal AKI, based on the site of the underlying cause. Postrenal AKI is further classified into upper or lower urinary tract obstruction, based on the level of the blockage.

The acute management of postrenal AKI begins with an ABCDE assessment (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) to determine patient stability. Patients who are unstable may report pelvic discomfort, poor urine stream, and urinary retention, and may have signs of volume overload (e.g., wheezing, rales, peripheral edema). Treatment parallels that for stable patients (e.g., Foley catheter placement for urinary retention), but with heightened attention to airway and breathing and prompt correction of electrolyte abnormalities. Depending on severity, noninvasive ventilation strategies, such as bilevel positive airway pressure, or emergent hemodialysis may be necessary when volume overload, hyperkalemia, severe metabolic acidosis, or symptomatic uremia are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent hemodialysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bilevel positive airway pressure:
Incorrect: Although there is evidence of volume overload, the patient is not in significant respiratory distress that requires noninvasive positive pressure ventilation. Hemodialysis is indicated for this patient’s life-threatening hyperkalemia.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate infusion:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate infusion is considered in acute kidney injury when there is severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.1) and no significant volume overload. It only provides a temporary intracellular shift of potassium, and its utility is limited based on current studies. Definitive removal of potassium in life-threatening hyperkalemia with acute kidney injury, as in this case, requires dialysis.
❌ Continuous bladder irrigation:
Incorrect: Continuous bladder irrigation is often used for hematuria with large clots or ongoing bleeding to promote continuous urine outflow and decrease the risk of developing postrenal acute kidney injury. This patient has no evidence of hematuria or continued urinary obstruction following Foley catheter placement.
❌ Ureteral stent placement:
Incorrect: Ureteral stent placement would be indicated for an upper urinary tract obstruction. However, this patient’s findings are more consistent with a lower urinary tract obstruction. Moreover, hemodialysis is indicated for the patient’s life-threatening hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and decreased urine output over the past week. There is associated fatigue and unintentional weight loss, but no fever, recent travel, or known exposure to infectious agents. Temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles, and there is 1+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Laboratory results are shown below. A chest X-ray demonstrates diffuse alveolar infiltrates consistent with pulmonary hemorrhage. The patient is started on emergent hemodialysis and high-dose intravenous (IV) glucocorticoids. 24 hours later, renal function continues to worsen. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Serum creatinine     5.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.7 mg/dL)    
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     72 mg/dL    
 Potassium     6.4 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     14 mEq/L    
 pH (arterial blood gas)     7.26    
 Complement C3     Normal    
 Complement C4     Normal    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM)     Positive    
 ANCA     Negative    
 Urinalysis     3+ blood, 2+ protein, RBC casts
questions.solution:
This patient presents with anti-GBM disease, confirmed by positive anti-GBM antibodies, pulmonary hemorrhage, and glomerulonephritis. Despite initial management with glucocorticoids and dialysis, the worsening renal function indicates ongoing antibody-mediated injury. Plasmapheresis is the best next step, as it rapidly removes circulating anti-GBM antibodies and helps prevent further damage to the lungs and kidneys. It should be used in combination with IV glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide to suppress antibody production and control inflammation.       

Management of intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI) due to glomerular causes includes both supportive care and targeted therapies. Supportive care addresses complications such as hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and volume overload, which may require dialysis.       

Disease-specific treatment depends on the underlying etiology. Glucocorticoids reduce inflammation in autoimmune conditions like lupus nephritis and ANCA-associated vasculitis. Additional immunosuppressive agents, including cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil, or rituximab, help limit immune activation and antibody production. In anti-GBM disease, plasmapheresis is particularly important for rapidly eliminating the pathogenic antibodies responsible for the disease process.   

Option Analysis

❌ Rituximab:
Incorrect: Rituximab is not a first-line treatment for anti-GBM disease. It has a delayed onset of action and is more commonly used in ANCA-associated vasculitis or refractory cases. Rapid antibody removal is necessary in this case, which rituximab does not provide.
✅ Plasmapheresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continued supportive care:
Incorrect: Supportive care alone does not address the underlying immune-mediated process in anti-GBM disease. Without removal of pathogenic antibodies through plasmapheresis, renal and pulmonary damage will likely worsen.  
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Incorrect: IVIG is not effective for treating anti-GBM disease and does not target the disease’s specific pathophysiology. It is used in other autoimmune disorders but is not appropriate in this context. 
❌ Switch to oral glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Transitioning to oral glucocorticoids is inappropriate in the acute setting. High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids are preferred initially to provide rapid immunosuppression.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department due to decreased activity and fever for three days. Parents have been giving her antipyretic agents for the fever. She has also had vomiting and diarrhea for two days. Past medical history is significant for seizure disorder that is well controlled on antiseizure medication. Temperature is 37� C (98.6�F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/48 mm Hg. There is no jaundice, skin rash or edema. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is greater than two seconds. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this condition? 

 Laboratory value      Result    
 Blood    
 pH      7.14    
 PCo2      42 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate     12 mmol/L    
 Serum    
 Potassium      4.6 mEq/dL    
 Blood urine nitrogen     30 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     1.7 mg/dL    
 Urine    
  pH     6    
 Protein      +1    
 RBCs     20/hpf    
 WBCs     2/hpf    
 Casts      Muddy brown casts
questions.solution:
This 4-year-old girl with dehydration and fever for which she has been receiving antipyretics and laboratory findings of metabolic acidosis, elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine, hematuria, proteinuria, and muddy brown casts likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a common cause of ATN.      
 
Prolonged or severe ischemia and nephrotoxic drugs can lead to necrosis, denuding of the epithelium, and occlusion of the tubular lumen by casts and cell debris which results in ATN. Any process associated with prerenal diseases, such as dehydration due to gastroenteritis, can cause ATN. In addition, there are a variety of nephrotoxins that can directly damage the renal tubules. Common drugs associated with ATN include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), aminoglycosides, amphotericin B, calcineurin inhibitors, and cisplatin. This patient has dehydration, fever and received NSAIDs which in combination can cause ATN.        

Patients with ATN may present with oliguria. Laboratory evaluation can show metabolic acidosis, elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen, hematuria, and proteinuria. Muddy brown granular casts, as seen in this patient, and epithelial cell casts are highly suggestive of ATN.   

Option Analysis

❌ Valproic acid  :
Incorrect: Valproic acid is an anticonvulsant that can lead to Fanconi syndrome, which usually presents with polyuria, generalized weakness, hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and proteinuria. This patient’s presentation and laboratory findings are more consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) which is associated with the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. 
✅ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acetaminophen :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen overuse may result in hepatotoxicity which may present with right upper quadrant pain or evidence of liver failure which is not noted in this patient. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute tubular necrosis which can be associated with the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. 
❌ Lamotrigine  :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant associated with Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically presenting with mucocutaneous reactions, fever, and severe mucositis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute tubular necrosis which can be associated with the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. 
❌ Carbamazepine  :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant, and chronic use may result in leukopenia, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia. It is not associated with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This patient’s clinical presentation and laboratory findings are more consistent with ATN which can be associated with the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is evaluated in the post-anesthesia care unit following open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that was complicated by moderate blood loss. Urine output from the foley catheter has decreased to 20 mL/hour over the past 4 hours. Past medical history is significant for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 112/min, blood pressure is 100/62 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is significant for dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. The abdomen is soft with a clean surgical incision. Laboratory findings are significant for a rise in serum creatinine from 1.1 mg/dL to 3.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 68 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IV 0.9% saline bolus followed by continuous infusion

questions.solution:
This patient with blood loss during surgery, decreased urine output, signs of hypovolemia, and acute kidney injury is likely experiencing prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). Operative patients are at risk for hypovolemia due to intraoperative blood loss. An intravenous (IV) bolus of 0.9% saline followed by a continuous infusion is appropriate to restore renal perfusion and prevent further kidney injury.

Initial steps in the acute management of postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) include assessing volume status and administering IV 0.9% saline in cases of hypovolemia. A thorough review of the patient’s medications should be performed to identify and discontinue nephrotoxic agents and to adjust doses for reduced renal clearance. Renal ultrasound may be performed to exclude intrarenal or postrenal causes. Bladder scan can be useful when there is urinary retention as a contributing factor. For patients with life-threatening conditions like pulmonary edema, refractory hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, uremic symptoms, or persistent anuria; hemodialysis or continuous renal replacement therapy may be indicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV 0.9% saline bolus followed by continuous infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A renal ultrasound could be used to evaluate for intrarenal and postrenal causes of acute kidney injury (AKI), however, this patient’s presentation suggests a prerenal etiology which should be treated with volume resuscitation.  
❌ Bladder scan:
Incorrect: A bladder scan is useful for assessing urinary retention, particularly in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). This patient already has a Foley catheter inserted, making a less likely cause of his oliguria.  
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is reserved for patients with acute kidney injury and severe hyperkalemia, acidosis, uremia, volume overload unresponsive to diuretics, or certain intoxications. This patient’s presentation suggests a prerenal etiology which should be treated with volume resuscitation.  
❌ Replace foley catheter:
Incorrect: Replacement of the foley catheter is considered when there is a suspicion of catheter blockage contributing to urinary retention. This patient’s clinical findings and laboratory results suggest a prerenal etiology of acute kidney injury (AKI) which requires volume resuscitation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is seen on the medical floor on post-op day 4 after emergent aortic valve repair for acute infective endocarditis complicated by aortic regurgitation. He tolerated the surgery well and it was uncomplicated. His urine output has decreased to 15 mL/hour. He received iodinated contrast dye for a preoperative CT scan performed on the same day as the surgery. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux and hypertension for which he takes omeprazole, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He is started on intravenous (IV) furosemide and a combination of IV vancomycin and gentamicin. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 86/min, blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is notable for bilateral lower extremity edema; and a tender, healing surgical site without signs of infection. Laboratory evaluation reveals a rise in serum creatinine to 3.4 mg/dL from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL, and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 30 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows muddy brown granular casts. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of acute kidney injury (AKI) with muddy brown granular casts, suggests acute tubular necrosis (ATN). ATN typically results from ischemic or nephrotoxic injury to the tubular epithelial cells. Aminoglycosides like gentamicin can be nephrotoxic and cause ATN. Gentamicin can lead to ATN by accumulating in the renal tubular cells, causing cellular damage and dysfunction.

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) results in a sudden decline in kidney function, evidenced by reduced urine output and a rise in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). Clinically, patients may present with symptoms of uremia such as nausea, fatigue, and confusion, with physical signs like edema and hypertension due to fluid overload. Urinalysis will show the presence of muddy brown granular casts, often accompanied by renal tubular epithelial cells or cell casts. A BUN/Cr ratio <15 and a fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) greater than 2% confirms a tubular source of kidney injury. Management of ATN centers on supportive care, addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalance, discontinuing nephrotoxic agents, and providing renal replacement therapy if indicated.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Gentamicin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: This patient with muddy brown casts in the urine likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like omeprazole can cause acute interstitial nephritis; however, this condition typically presents with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. The absence of these findings and the presence of muddy brown granular casts is more suggestive of ATN from gentamicin.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: This patient with muddy brown casts in the urine likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from gentamicin ACE inhibitors like lisinopril, which can contribute to acute kidney injury (AKI) by reducing the glomerular filtration rate– especially in the setting of renal artery stenosis, heart failure, or diuretic use. However, they are less likely to cause ATN and muddy brown casts.  
❌ Iodinated contrast dye:
Incorrect: This patient with muddy brown casts in the urine likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from gentamicin. While iodinated contrast dye can cause ATN, it generally leads to a rise in serum creatinine within 48 hours post-exposure not 4-5 days later.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient with muddy brown casts in the urine likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Furosemide can lead to intravascular volume depletion and prerenal azotemia but is less likely to cause ATN with muddy brown casts unless there is significant hypotension.
